name: 2,4-dichlorobenzamide
Reason: The compound 2,4-dichlorobenzamide comprises a benzene ring as a base unit, an amide group, and two chloro substituents. The base unit for benzene has a melting point of 5.5 °C. The amide group will significantly increase the melting point due to strong intermolecular hydrogen bonding capabilities, and I estimate this impact at around +140 °C. The chloro substituents both will increase the melting point as well due to increased molecular weight and van der Waals forces, as well as possible induction of polarity. Each chloro group could add approximately +15 °C to the melting point. Summing the effects gives us an estimated increase of 170 °C collectively. Therefore, I predict that the melting point of 2,4-dichlorobenzamide would be approximately 175.5 °C.

name: 2,4-dichlorobenzamide
Reason: The compound 2,4-dichlorobenzamide comprises a benzene ring as a base unit, an amide functional group, and two chloro substituents. The base benzene has a melting point of 5.5°C. Amide groups strongly increase melting points due to the potential for intermolecular hydrogen bonding; I estimate this to add approximately +150°C. Each chloro substituent adds to the melting point due to increased molecular weight, additional van der Waals interactions, and enhanced polarity; I estimate each chloro group to add around +18°C. Therefore, collectively the functional groups add an estimated +186°C to the base benzene melting point.
